Collation: The journal contains 118 pages arranged as follows: 1 (blank paste-down endpaper); 2 (blank except for "1/9" written in the upper right-hand corner); 3 (blank except for "1" written in the upper left-hand corner; 4-40 (journal entries on pages numbered 1 through 37 consecutively, odd numbers in the upper right-hand corners, even numbers in the upper left-hand corners of pages); 41-117 (blank pages); 118 (list of outgoing mail on a paste-down endpaper). The text block consists of a gathering of four quires of 6, 20, 16, and 18 leaves—including the paste-down endpapers in the first and last quires—sewn through the fold and glued (?) to the binding.

Watermark
Watermark
Paper: The pages of the journal consist of cream-colored paper, 20.5 cm wide by 25.8 cm tall, with 1.5 cm top and bottom unlined margins. The body of the pages contains 28 horizontal blue lines spaced 0.8 cm apart and a vertical red line defining a 2.54 cm left margin. Some pages contain all or part of a 10 x 7.4 cm oval watermark depicting a seated female figure holding a spear in the crook of her right arm and leaves in her extended left hand. A 3 x 5 cm crown sits above the oval. Paper Watermarks identifies a nearly identical watermark with stationers Waterlow Bros. & Layton, London; however, the watermark illustrated on Paper Watermarks contains the decorative initials "WBL" below the oval. Another page of the journal bears the watermark "Original Superfine."

Binding: Dark brown leather over buckram-wrapped boards. The leather is worn and chipped, exposing buckram, and the front cover is embossed with "THE ACADEMY" (centered) and "REORDER NO. 411" (lower righthand corner). The spine is unmarked. The top, bottom, and fore-edge of the text block are stippled.

Loose Radiograms: Twenty-five loose radiograms are tucked inside the back cover of the bound journal. The radiograms fall into two groups: typed copies of radiograms Lockhart received via the Army Amateur Radio Service from friends and family, and typed drafts of outgoing messages. The incoming radiograms are all on cream-colored onionskin measuring 20.2 cm wide by 13.5 cm tall with two spiral binding holes along one edge (in all but one case at the top of the message). The outgoing messages are on heavier cream-colored paper, most measuring 21.6 cm wide by 14 cm tall except for three from April 1941 measuring 21.5 cm wide by 17.6 cm tall.

item.name: Sheila
item.desc: In his entry for January 5, 1941, Lockhart recounts an occasion on which Sheila tried to bite him, misbehavior that causes Lockhart to violate his general rule of not hitting the dogs.

item.name: Spot
item.desc: In a radiogram to his sister dated January 4, 1941 and in his journal entry for January 5, 1941, Lockhart notes that he hopes to take Spot, his "lead dog," home with him.

H. Lewis Ulman is Associate Professor of English at The Ohio State University and Director of Digital Media Studies in the Department of English. He has edited The Minutes of the Aberdeen Philosophical Society, 1758–1773 (Aberdeen University Press, 1990) and, with Dennis Quon, “Semiotics in Eighteenth-century Aberdeen: Thomas Gordon’s Contributions to the Aberdeen Philosophical Society” (Studies on Voltaire and the Eighteenth-Century 317 (1994): 57–115). He is also the author of Things, Thoughts, Words and Actions: The Problem of Language in Late Eighteenth-Century British Rhetorical Theory (Southern Illinois University Press, 1994). Since 2005, he has worked with undergraduate and graduate students in textual editing courses to create a series of electronic textual editions of nineteenth- and early twentieth-century American manuscripts in the Rare Books and Manuscripts Library at Ohio State. An example of that work can be viewed online at http://people.cohums.ohio-state.edu/ulman1/SSCoxJournal/. Beginning with an NEH Digital Humanities Start-Up Grant awarded in 2008, he has collaborated with Melanie Schlosser, metadata librarian at Ohio State University Libraries, to build a model of preservation for distributed, multimodal digital humanities projects. He is delighted to be working at a time when manuscript, print, and digital media can be studied in relationship to one another, allowing him and his students to learn more about all three media than they could by studying any one in isolation.

projectDesc.p: This edition is the latest in a series of collaboratively produced electronic editions of previously unpublished nineteenth-century American manuscripts held in the Rare Books and Manuscripts Library at The Ohio State University. Previous editions include "My Dear Elizabeth," five letters written by Sophia Peabody Hawthorne to her sister Elizabeth Palmer Peabody between ca. 1837 and 1868 (currently being revised); "Dear Wife," twenty-one letters written by riverboat captain William B. Anderson to his wife Louisa while he plied the Ohio river during the height of the American Civil War, 1862–1864; "Journal of a Tour to Europe," by Samuel Sullivan Cox; and "Louisa A. Doane's Journal of Two Ocean Voyages (1852-1853). These documentary editions are intended to provide wide exposure and access to manuscripts that might otherwise be difficult for scholars to discover and consult, and to provide users with a variety of tools for studying those texts.

Each text was edited in connection with an undergraduate or graduate course offered by H. Lewis Ulman, Associate Professor of English at The Ohio State University. The courses provide students with an opportunity to explore issues of textuality and mediation that arise when our cultural archives spread from page to screen and from library shelves to networked databases. Electronic textual editing serves as our vehicle for examining what happens—and envisioning what might happen—when artifacts in one medium are represented in another medium, especially with regard to the interpretive work of reading. Electronic textual editions also provide a contact zone that can help us reflect on what manuscript, print, and "born digital" artifacts can tell us about their unique properties and their relationships to one another.

While providing a reliable textual edition is a sine qua non, the Lockhart edition also explores ways of telling four stories inextricably woven into our work: the lives and historical milieu evoked by the texts, the history of the physical journal, the editorial process that gave rise to this particular interpretation of the text, and the mediation of our electronic delivery system.

editorialDecl.p: Scanning. The manuscript pages were scanned as 24-bit TIFF images at 400 dots per inch (dpi), then coverted to 8-bit JPEG images at 400 dpi and full quality before being loaded into the Media Manager application. All edges were overscanned by at least 1/4 inch. No color correction was used at any stage of image preparation, but a scan of a photographer's 18% grey card on the same scanner produced RGB values at the center of 91/95/107 after applying a 150% Gaussian Blur in Adobe Photoshop to average color values. Thus, a properly configured monitor should provide a reasonable approximation of colors on the manuscript pages.

Production Location of Digital Assets. The TEI P5-encoded transcription of the Smith journal, along with XSL style sheets used to provide variant "views" of the edition, TEI ODD documents used to produce custom schemas based on the TEI markup language, and the resulting schemas are stored on a server hosted by College of Arts and Sciences at The Ohio State University and on a Google SVN repository. Readers may download copies of those source files via a link at the top of this page. High resolution scans of the manuscript pages, scans of plates from contemporary sources, and photographs of the journal are stored in the Media Manager application hosted by the College of Arts and Science at The Ohio State University. The files constituting the project's Web site are stored on a Web server hosted by the College (http://people.cohums.ohio-state.edu/ulman1/LCSmithDiaries/).
Archiving of Digital Assets. Once the edition is complete, its digital assets will be archived in The Ohio State University Knowledge Bank (https://kb.osu.edu/dspace/).

refsDecl.p: Markup of Physical Structure and Page Layout. The manuscript pages, encoded by the empty page break or <pb/> element, are the primary physical structures represented in the markup. Each <pb> element includes a "facs" attribute identifying the unique ID of a high-resolution scan of that image in the Media Manager application. Line breaks (i.e., lineation determined or influenced by the physical constraints of the page rather than compositional choices by the author) are encoded with the empty <lb/> element. No attributes are included in the <lb> element. Because Smith wrote on lined paper, when he skips a line printed on the paper for any reason, we encode a <lb/> that, in the view arranged by manuscript pages and lines, will appear as an empty numbered line.

Markup of Textual Structure. The diary entry, encoded by a <div> element with the attribute-value pair "type='Entry'", constitutes the primary textual structure represented in the markup. Each entry contains a <dateline> element and one or more paragraphs. Each dateline may include a <name> element with (optionally) a @type attribute containing one of the following values: city, region; and a <date> element with a @when attribute whose value is in the form YYYY-MM-DD. The value of the @when attribute represents the editors' judgment about the actual date when the entry was composed; the contents of the <date> element represent what Smith actually wrote, even if he entered the date incorrectly.

Entries consist of a series of paragraphs. Where indicated by context, indentation of a line from the left margin of a page, line breaks part-way across a page, or additional white space between lines, paragraphs are encoded with the

element and no attributes.
If present, any prefatory text preceding the dateline may be encoded as a <head> element at the beginning of an entry (i.e., within the <div>element and before the <dateline>).

Level of Transcription/Encoding. This markup scheme supports a modest range of presentations, from semi-modernized/corrected to semi-diplomatic. The basic transcription follows the manuscript verbatim. Various manuscript features (e.g., cancellations, interlinear or marginal additions, tears in pages) are encoded, as are regularized versions of proper names and dates and standard versions of nonstandard spellings and expansions of abbreviations.

Customization of the TEI P5 Schema. Customization consisted primarily of restricting encoding to certain modules and elements as well as enforcing some attribute values. See the ODD file for complete details.

body.head:
Journal covering period Dec 25 1940 until return home
about May 1st 1941

div.p:
At the exact moment when christmas bells should have
begun ringing here in the Antarctic if any christmas bells
had been available, Pack Jack Tony and I were making
our last big "Putsch" toward the base We had left
Fort Wiener at 930 PM and at 11 PM when we were
only 10.5 miles from the base decided not to camp until
morning but push on in. Tony and the rest While we were
resting we drank a toast to ourselves — as a party — and
to a merry christmas, finishing up the half a pint which
I had nursed along so carefully for two and a half months. Tony
and I started out again and again and for a while had some
difficulty staying ahead of the dogs. They were running now
just as well as they did when we first hit the good
surface we were travelling over. Jack and Sevene still
combining new teams and he was driving them. Dinch and
Pearl were pinched up in the loads. I am quite certain
that we should never have made the base when we did
if we hadn't combinded our teams. At one o'clock we
could just see the base and the airplane looming on the
horizon. Tony had been seeing things for several hours
but always he had to say I guess I was wrong
when a large trail flag br came into view. All sorts
of thoughts began clicking through our minds as the base
2
became larger and larger. Tonybr, I know, was especially
anxious to get into the barracks to tell his stories. The
rest of us were wondering what the present set up was like-
we had heard so many reports while we were out on the trail
that we had no idea what we were walking into. I
think the thought uppermost in our minds was food. While
we were out on the trail we were perfectly satisfied with our
somewhat rigid diet but now that we were approaching some-
thing of quite different. I said that I probable wouldn't eat very much
Peuk said he would eat only a ham sandwich and a cup of coffee.
TonyandJack said they were going to fill up. We all had our
doubts whether Gutenko would have anything for us.

When we had come about 2 miles from the base,Tony
and I stopped Jack who was leading and suggested that we
let Peuk take his team in first. Tony skied ahead breaking
trail with Peuk following a short distance behind I skied
ahead of old Spot.Paul came out to meet us and gave
us a good hand clapp as we came up to him. There was
preliminary gossip as we endrived in. We parked in
front of the balloon house where we were met by almost the
whole camp personnel. We had been wondering whether any
but a dozen few would be waiting up for us and now were
surprised to see everyone. While we were answering various
questions we net up camp and staked out the dogs. Douglas
and Wiener hauled over some seal meat they had cut. The
dogs sure enjoyed it and then yelped for more. By that time
Gutenko said that clun was nearly ready and we all repaired to
3
the barracks. We took our clothes off and weighed in.
Peuk weighed 193 before and 173 after (in same clothes) Jack
weighed 159 before and about 158 after. Tony weighed 189
before and 163 after I weighed 162 before and 150 after.
Those of us who lost weight lost only the fat that we had
put on during the winter night. Gutenko really put out a
meal. tomato juice, tomato soup steak potatoes and even
figs for dessert and coffee. I really ate my share thus
not living up to the statement I made on the trail. We
had come in at 2AM having covered the 34 miles in less
than 16 hours which was very good time considering the stops
we made, this surface and the condition we and the dogs
were in. Then we sat around and talked for several more
hours. Jack and I went out to sleep in the tent but Tony
and Peuk stayed inside. It was almost six oclock before
we got out there Arnold came out with us and fed us with
some of the dish and there was a lot of it.

I slept the sleep of the blessed for about three hours and
then dozed for about three hours f more. Jack and Doug
talking in the next tent convinced me that it was time to get
up. after dressing I went into the galley to have my first
different breakfast in several months. There was fruit toast
cheeze and coffee and I had pleanty of all. From then
on I spent the time until dinner cleaning up a little and
chewing the fat a lot. The dinner was one of the Gutenko's specials
turkey with sweet potatoes asparagus spinach
dressing cranberry sauce after boullim; we had a little
4
christmas spirit and strawberry pie to top things off then
more lulling until show time. We saw the Jones family in
Hollywood and Risky Business. I enjoyed both of them.

It had been blowing about 35-40 miles an hour all day
and drifting so badly that I decided to sleep in. Jack
however braved the storm and slept out. All in

All in all this has by far been the most eventful
christmas I have ever experienced.

The base has been operating on a very peculiar schedule
since the trail parties went out. Gutenko gets up about 1-2
PM and works preparing the only meal of the day a dinner
The rest of the men get up anytime between 2 and 6 and then
stay up until they get tired enough to go to bed again about
6-7-8 in the morning. The only work being done around camp
is general duty and evacuation work- not much of the latter
as yet. The camp is divided into two groups each of which
does the cleaning up and galley duty in alternate days. In
off moments the fellows go skiing and walking with the dogs.
All of the pups which were hardly able to walk when we
left now have the run of the camp. They certainly are a
nice bunch. Pappy Gray has those which he harnesses to
the airplane sled and drives around. In general the men
here haven't much to do and take their time doing it.
The men who have regular schedules to meet such as the
radio men and the weather man appear at their regular
intervals but otherwise any semblance of regularity has
disappeared. I was puzzled to see such a system of what
5
we have here now in a system but learned that it
all came about because the best time for taking
airplane pictures is in the early morning hours. During
the flying day when everyone was waiting for breaks in
the weather this new arrangement of sleeping days and
staying up nights became the vogue. We of the biological
party are finding it difficult to change from the rigorous
schedule we have been observing to this not so rigorous
one of the base.

For the first time since we left the base I have
been really sore in my muscles. I don't know whether
it is due to the long run made on the last day or to
the lack of any follow up exercise today.

All of the radiograms that had come in during my absence
were given to me. One of them had not been read over the air
It was from Beatie and wished me a merry christmas. The main
item of the message, however, lead me to believe that some of my
friends would not have a merry christmas; Jack Mahan's father
died about a week ago. I was very sorry to hear of it allthoughalthough
I had been expecting it. Evidently his exceptionally strong heart
just couldn't stand up any longer under the high pressure. It
is better that he is gone because for several years he has
been very unhappy about his condition particularly because he
realized that there was no hope of his ever recovering. I
always enjoyed the moments I spent with him talking
about boats and travel. I'm certain he would have been
interested to hear about the trip I am now about to com-
6
plete. Beatie did not say whether Jack came home for
the funeral. Since Ned and Bill have gotten married and
have moved out on their own only Mrs. Mahan and Margaret
will be living in Arlington Street.

I slept very well in my old cloth bag. I am lost now
that I don't have a watch and consequently with the present
schedule I didn't know whether I should get up or try to go
back to sleep. The predicament was relieved by Arnold who
happened to pass by. I got up when he said it was 11 30
The whole biological party was in the galley preparing breakfast
egg toast fig prunes coffee. Already I have forgotten how
delicious were the oatmeal and cocoa of the trail. Although I
meant to get going on my cleaning up for metabolism tests
but I started writing reading and talking so very little was
done. Buck Boyd and Sweet skiing down to the barrier edge
to see if the blizzard had carried out any of the bay ice.
We found that the whole bay was still iced over and unless
something drastic happens within the next two weeks we certainly
are going to have a very difficult time getting out of this place.
Well we shan't worry about that for a while.

I forgot to mention in yesterday's account that the tractor
had gone into a crevase about 10 miles from 105 and the
situation looked impossible. Since the storm was raging out
there nothing could be done at the moment. Today at the
the radio schedule time we were happy to learn that the
7
impossible situation had been overcome; the tractor and
its loads had passed the crevasse had gotten into
another small one but was able to keep going and had
arrived at 105. Some of the boys will now continue home
with their dog teams. Larry will stay with the tractor
gang and with his dog team attempt to evacuate Fritz.

At this time—about 2 AM—I don't feel particularly
tired so am staying up. I hadved been reading Death
Sails with Magellan but stopped to help Count release
one of his raysenderadiosonde ballonsballoons. It got caught in one of
Railey's antennas but I was able to climb the pole
and free it. While helping him I noticed a bunch
of skua gulls on a refuse pile and decided to try my
skill again. I walked carefully toward them with
the revolver ready but two of the pups came up
passed me and scared them away. Next time I
shall make sure there are no pups around when I
go after the gulls.

I woke up several times during the night and
wondered each time whether I shouldn't get up. Always
there were men stirring around, the same light was
shining the window so I was continually confused
as to the time. I realized at last that it was time to
get up when I heard the stove being made. I knew
then it was noon time. I got up and made my own
8
as is the custom. I made some beautiful
ham scrambled eggs from frozen whole eggs milk butter
salt and nutmeg; they really were delicious. To go with
them I had cherries toast and coffee. After breakfast
I started cleaning uo my joint and decided to do some
washing at the same time. During the day I washed
two pairs of underwear and two woolen shirts. I still
have some socks and mitt liners in the wash water.
Other clothing I packed into the duffle bag and I got that
out from under my feet. Glassware began to go into
the sink and little by little order appeared out of chaos.
The job isn't complete yet but it is well on its way
and another day should see me ready for work. One
of the big jobs was the clearing of the Haldane apparatus
and all day job if there ever was one - those damned
stop cocks take years off my life. Just before dinner
Perk and I went out and chopped seal meat, this
semi frozen stuff is a cinch to cut compared with that
we had in the tunnels. The dogs hardly know what to
make of the seal meat. While on the trail their blocks
would be chewed and swallowed within a minute or two
but now only after a great deal of labor do they get enough
real meat from the big chuncks to make a good mouthful.
After dinner those of us who had no chores during the
day were asked to fill the snow melter. The snow
melter requires filling only about once every five days
as compared with every other day during the old regime.

10
I prepared what will probably be my usual piece-de-resistance
scrambled eggs ala Lockhart. These with toast and coffee
completed the morning repast.

In the laboratory I learned up a little more and am now
ready to begin metabolism tests in the morning. Tony will
be the first victim. I also changed water on the socks I
had been soaking overnight and then sat down to read a bit
more in Death Sails with Magellan. Charles Ford the
author certainly had done a marvellous job in this book
I shall have to get it for my own library when I get home.
Just as Buck and I were going out skua gull hunting
Paul stopped me to show some of the airplane pictures.
Hal Flood is certaintly a large and beautiful mountain
He also said that he was going to see if it wouldn't
be possible to name one of thea mountain in the region
beyond Hal Flood after each one of the members of the
Expedition. I think that would be quite something and
hope the idea will be approved. Buck and I did not
get any skua gulls—he is not the shot he professes to be.
In the future before the ships come in—by the way, it is said
that the Bear has already left New Zealand for the Bay—
I shall do a little target practicing every day. Pete has
just come in saying that there were more skua gulls out
there and brought in one as evidence.

Even I spoke to Bailey about getting a contact with the
folks. He said that although conditions were very bad he
would speak to Charlie. It is so little trouble for them to
11
get over there that it is worth the chance they will be
taking.

There is going to be a mail lag sponsored by the Boston
Traveler in Jan 31. We may not be able to get it
here because the ships will be on their way or almost
ready to go. It won't be worth whileworthwhile to tell the folks
to say a few words to me. It won't be very long now
until I see them again anyway.
Enough for now.

Not long after Pete brought his skua gull in Wiener went out
with his 22 rifle and brought back two more which Pete
immediately worked on for blood samples. He had some trouble
getting the birds to bleed and then trouble getting the blood to
centrifuge properly. I made a few suggestions such as using
oxalate to prevent the blood from coagulating and the faster centrifugation
of the fresh blood. I hope to kill a few more so that I can skin them
and salt them down to take back.

After dinner I got a few things ready for the morning metabolism
test on Tony and then spent some time bringing in coal and taking
out the garbage, chores assigned to me or my share in today's
cleaning up. The rest of the evening was spent in reading. While
I was out feeding the dogs, Pete and Bailey killed a few skua gulls
with the shotgun. It is lucky that the gulls are not
yet accustomed to the shots or there would be much less fewer
targets available.

I shall go to bed about 1:30 and get in a few hours sleep be
12
before the metabolism tests take place.

I had a very difficult time getting up this morning. Although
I wanted to get up at 10 it was close to 11 before I descended
from my heaven. I dressed and then woke Tony. The metabolism
test did not go off very well and we shall repeat it. We
finished up just in time for me to take the noon observation
and change the sheets. In the afternoon I began jumping
the gas analysis apparatus and after finishing that made an
end of Death Sails with Magellan. No gun practice today
After dinner got ready for the usim analysis and completed
my sock washing. Then came the seal chopping chore. The dogs
sure make a fuss over the seal meat probably because they
are getting plenty of it. Iut brought in the first Adelie
penguin and Pete has been spending most of the evening
drawing blood and skinning it. There should be more of them
in one the ice within the next few days. Asman and Pete took
the tank out for a spin and were not able to get it up out of
the bight so they left it there. They gave it another try tonight
but it was no soap. They will have to wait a while longer until
the surface gets a little harder. They The boys don't do much
work around here but they do sit and chew the fat. More
arguementsarguments can arise over the most obscure—and some not
so obscure—topics that I have ever imagined. Right
now the cook who has been considered—by himself—an authority
on almost any subject one can bring up has been telling the boys
13
that he rolls the oranges before squeezing out the the juice in order
to get the citric acid out of the skin. Shirley argues that he
rolls the oranges in order to break the skin and the cellular
structure inside. They appealed to me being the chemist to
settle the argument. I tried to steer clear but finally sided
with Shirley which action made the cook leak water a
little --- but not much.

I began reading Gone with the Wind and hope it won't
take too much of my time.

I have come back from the trail with an intense desire to
do some more camping - preferably in Canada - and all the
other activities that go with it hunting and fishing. I
presume that the best way to begin is to go some advertised
camp and hire a guide for a week or so. I shall get

I shall get out of this mess line and go to bed where
I can read in peace.

div.dateline:
Wednesday January 1 1941
At last the new year has Tuesday December 31 1941
div.p:
We have been operating such an erratic schedule and
also have to deal with Greenwich Mean Time that
I have been confused concerning the day and date for
several days. Yesterday I thought today was to be New Year
and now that we are actually in the New Year by camp
schedule I am still during today. Now, however, I think
I am fairly well straightened out.

Yesterday which normally would have been written up early
this morning slipped by with no entry entirely because I had
gotten so far into Gone with the Wind that wartime was a thing
of minor importance. I read that amazing episnarrative of life
among the Southerners during the Civil War days until almost
AM. I wasn't reading all of the time but enough of the time
so that work which should be the main object these days
stagnated. The book which begins I mildly and almost
boringly soon gets under way and its power makes itself
evident. The South which has been a mystery to me and
no doubt to countless other Americans will soon become in
my mind something more than the land of cotton, belles,
"gentlemen" and mint juleps. Perhaps even the answer to
the legendary or hereditary hate most Southerners have
for Northeners in general would be evident. At any rate
I felt then that I should get a little American History into

my head in an entirely pleasant manner. Now after
having continued my reading through that part of the book
in which the war has ended and the "Cause" lost do I do
begin to get the idea underlying all of the hatred that has
been instilled in the present generation by parents, grand
parents or even great grand parents the latter of whom were
the younger generation of those never-to-be-forgotten days.
If the Yankees had been able to win the war without
the Sherman-in-Atlanta episode perhaps all of the
stigma which now is attached thto the word Northener
might have been avoided. Conerning the Civil War no
one can say "that's all ancient History" because in
the South, as far as I can gather from some of the Southern boys
here, the Civil War is still being fought with almost the
same intensity as in the days of the actual war itself. I
am now about to embark on the history of the post war days
which are to be considered as bad if not worse than those
the war days themselves.

Yesterday I worked on Tony again and today should have
worked of on Jack Richardson but he was up even later
than I so I didn't bother to wake him at ten this morning.

Last night part of the time was spent analyzing air
samples that had been taken outside. The interesting part
of this work was the very low percentage of oxygen in the air
the carbon dioxide value which was relatively quite high
was not as accurate a result as the oxygen value so cannot
hold as much importance as the latter. In taking these
16
samples I am cooperating with Court the meteorologist who
tells me when to take the samples. The prime requisite is
that the wind must have been blowing steadily from one
direction for more than six hours. I shall do as many
of these analyses as time and energy — mostly energy — will
permit. When correlated with the weather data Court has they
should be of some value to whomever studies that sort of
thing. My interest in the matter lies only in the fact that
I may be the only man for some time to come who will have
an accurate apparatus for gas analysis here in the Antarctic.

I tried to get some shots at skua gulls with the hand
gun but evidently they have become somewhat man shy because
I couldn't get close enough to shoot. I shall have to learn
to shoot the shot gun so that I can get them ion the wing.

Tonight at radio schedule time we learned that the boys
want to abandon the tractor; they just can't make any progress
at all. The tractor goes into the snow up to its belly even
with no load. In order not to lose the valuable loads which
have been made even heavier by the addition of the outpost's
stuff it has been decided to send Tony and Jack out with
18 dogs and two sleds. Ferranto is hauling several dog sleds
which are extra so that the single do sled dog teams can
once more be brought ba made double sled dog teams. At
least Tony and Jack will be able to carry home all the gear
our party left with the tractor and probably some besides. We
sure hope that the scientific specimens can be brought back.

Jack Perkins has just completed some beautiful jobs on the
17
Adelie an Emperor and a snowy petrel. The skins have
turned out beautifully.

Yesterday I had messages from mamma and Beatie
and in mamma's she said that she was expecting a penguin
skin and since there seem to be plenty of Emperors around
perhaps I should get busy and skin one myself. I
hope to get an Adelie at least later on. They are small
enough to not to be totoo bothersome and would make
something really unique for a den. I hope also to get
a skua gull and a snowy petrel but the chances are
I shan't be able to.

I had a message from the Guernsey'sGuernseys today wh
wishing me a happy new year and a safe return. I
have also had a message from Mary and Carl but at the
moment I can't remember what day it came in. I
certainly am anxious to get home. I can see now that
I shan't spend much time travelling across country. When
I start for home I shall want to get there as soon as
possible.

We almost made a broadcast today. This is the second
time I have almost made one from down here. Wager
the short wave director and sponsor of the Mail Bag wanted
to have both bases say something for New Years to the folks
in the United States. Conditions have been so bad recently
that little hope for a strong signal was held. They
had trouble pulling East Base through but they finally did
It was not until about an hour and a half later that our
18
signal came through strongly enough for rebroadcasting.
The signal strength held only for a few minutes and not
long enough for our choral singing to take place. At
the last minute almost a few of us worked out the words
to Auld Lang Syne and Show Me the Way to Go Home. None
of us knew all of both songs completely. Pete was to
accompany us with his ukeukelele. Just as we were about to
go on our signal strength dropped and our chance was
gone. Ah well another time maybe.
And now to bed.

Happy new year! This is one of the strangest new years
I have had since I can rembe remember. Its strangeness
lies in the fact that it is just like any other day I have had
since my return to camp. More likely it will be similar to
Christmas a week ago in that we shall have turkey but beyond
that it's just another day to be marked off on the calendar
signifying that one less day must be lived through until the
ships come, depart and we are home again.

Home again! What visions in the future that small phrase
conjures up! All though Although I am certain I have work
which will be of some inor importance in the scientific literature
the greatest gain comes to me in a personal way. I am now
a firm believer that one trained so completely in theoretical matters
as I have been in the past should go away on an expedition for
a year or two; there in this small world of ours, for instance, one
19
meets men from many walks of life and learns quickly
to adjust oneself to meet each personality. One learns
the meaning of work and what a working man thinks
about the type of work not requiring a strong back and
plenty of perspiration. One learns many new handicrafts
under the guidance - half heart half hearted sometimes to be sure -
of men who might be chrosed as masters of their cots. If one
is so priviledged that hisones work involves a trail trip then the
art of living among the elements and on only the bare necessities
one acquires a confidence, an assurance and an interest
in things utterly foreign to one's early training and profits
according to one's ability to absorb and retain. Many small
never-to-be-forgotten incidents are engraved in one's mental
filing cabinet and whether or not they serve as the basis for
future activities remain if only as memories. It is as though
an encyclopedia of many phases of life has been opened; those
with eyes ear and tongue profit. I am sure that my
home life in the future will be immeasurably more pleasant
because I have invested several years to reap my interest
some time later. Time alone will tell the actual value of this
trip to the Antarctic and the time when dividends should be
showing begins almost immediately.

Alarm clocks have no place in my system of living. Never
have I used one as a constant companion and now that
I am using one I don't go by it. Since I have been trying to
20
to get up at least by ten in order to run metabolism tests
I have borrowed Court's alarm clock but when it rings I
just shut it off without waking up and go back to sleep. Some
of the fellows ask me to call them at specific times but usually I
forget until sometime later. No damage has been done yet.

There was some excitement here last night. I didn't stay up
to follow it completely but did get in on the tail end. The trail
parties have been dogged unfortunately by soft surface and heavy
loads and are getting low on gas for the tractor and dog food.
Last night after the schedule the airplane gang decided to take the
Condor out with supplies and bring back some of the load.
The weather was not so hot with some overcast coming in from
the east. They took off about 11PM and soon reported that
the overcast was becoming heavier. Not long after they said they
saw the dog teams at 71 but because of overcast could not land.
They passed over the expectant men and flew on to the tractor
party which was at 92. There they were able to land leave some
food and gas and take on some load. As they rose into
the air to make another attempt to land at 71, the star
board motor began sputtering and finally died altogether.
The plane made a safe landing at about 80 midway
between the parties and after making a rapid check up
found that #4 cylinder had failed and the piston had
gone right through the cowling. Since this was the master
cylinder things looked black. Pete and Pappy warmed
up the Beechcraft and took off about 2:30 AM Pappy had
all the spare cylinder gear he could find in the shop but
21
to no avail what was needed was a complete new engine.
Pete brought back Poppy and Giles and then went out
for Paul and Mac. Pete had to go all the way to the
tractor and then to the plane. The overcast that had been
increasing had become so bad that Pete was afraid
he had missed the plane when he had flown some time
and had just decided to make tloback tracks back to
the base when the Condor loomed up. He landed too and
while Paul and Mac were getting ready took off again
accompanied by Paul with food and dog food for the dog team parties. They
could fly no more than 25 feet off the ground - overcast
pinning them down but made the trip of 10 miles successfully .
After a few minutes of greetings and fare wells they went
back to the Condor. After packing in as much gear as the
little plane would stand the three men turned for home
leaving the Condor in what will probably be her last
landing place. She tried to do her job but just wasn't
good enough. Pete had some difficulty getting down here
at the base but landed safely. Now the trail parties
will have to battle their way in and the Beechcraft will
make some flights out to the Condor to salvage some of the
valuable instruments such as the drift indicator worth about
$1500. We all are happy that the accident didn't happen
when the Condor was 500 miles from the base.

My reading has tended to be southern in nature.
After finishing Gone with the Wind I started in on South
Moon Under and found it to be concerned with poor
22
whites in Florida. I have spoken to Shirley about it and
hope he reads it. I should like to know if it at all aw
accurate picture of the state where he lived much of his boyhood.
Gone with the Wind tapered off slightly in interest and left me
hanging in the air. I am not certain whether Rhett Butler
and Scarlett should have found happiness or whether the ending
as Margaret Mitchell made it was more in keeping with the
whole tone of the book and a just reward for Scarlett. As I
read the book and thought about the movie that has been made
from it Clark Gable certainly is the man to play Rhett Butler
I am not so sure about Vivien Leigh as Scarlett!

We had a mail bag today from Kansas City but the re-
ception fell off so abruptly after the variety here that the letters
were heard only very indistinctly. I know I had one letter from
mamma but couldn't even get the gist of the letter.

Asman has been taking the tank out every night now that
the temperature has fallen somewhat. He is trying to make a
hard path from here to the old cache so that he can get
some of the boxes down there. Tonight he got stuck and had to
abandon a load he was attempting to haul.

Got in another air analysis but aside from that I have done
nothing constructive all day. I've got to get in the half.

The ice shows no signs of breaking out of the Bay. It sure
will be a job loading if some of it at least doesn't go out - and
soon.

Until the ships arrive, the days will be quite the same
only occasional variation will relieve the monotony which is
heightened because the hour of departure is indeed not far off.
The variety of today's routine was the trip I took with the dogs
down to the Bay. After dinner I got Tony to help me haul
a seal out of the tunnel and in order to have something to feed
the dogs after we got back. While we were waiting for
Grant who was to accompany us Tony and I dug out the
sled and harnessed the dogs. Tony then skied off in the
direction of the tank which had stopped about 1/2 mile from
camp. I had put on my skiis and was about to reach the
ge pole when the team started with Court aboard. I
shouted myself hoarse in thirty seconds trying to get them
to stop. Spot could hear me and wanted to stop but
the onward ruch of my nea quartet that really wanted to
go made him keep going. They finally stopped several
hundred yards out of camp. When I came up they were
stil very anxious to get going but I made them get down
and wait for my command to go. Spot answered the
commands very well and we headed toward the tank which
had started back toward the camp. Tony thought he would
ski ahead and make a trail so that the team would follow
but the team went right by him. I stopped and he joined
Court in the shed giving me a load of about 300 lbs. The dogs
were breathing hard now but their enthusiasm was unlimited.
Spot was right out in front with his line tight and behaved
24
beautifully. We finally hit the trail to the barrier cache
and as we headed toward it we saw PappyGreg in the
distance with his great team of three dogs. I stopped
and waited for him to come up and there he followed me
down to the barrels. We parked the teams and went to the
edge and saw several seals spouting in one of the cracks
Those seals don't know it yet but they will become dog meat
before long: We shall take the whole bunch of dogs down to
the barrier hill seals and haule them to the top big dogs and
after cleaning them bring them back to camp.

A great deal of ice is just about ready to crack out and
a good strong sough wind should carry out a great deal
of it. With only about a week to go before The Bear gets
here perhaps much of it will go out.

We finally headed for home with my dogs leading.
Iuti dogs kept right bahind and in a few minutes we were
back in camp.

I then fed the dogs and left them tire but contented
Before going to bed I did an air sample and read a
little. After I was in bed I also read. My bedtime reading
consists of Homo enows by Darwin a discussion of Darwin
then most recent book The Descent of Man. I bought the former
in New Zealand to accompany the latter which I have at home

It was three AM before I turned out the light. I was
fearful for my early rising but I didn't have anything particular
to do tomorrow so I can sleep in if I feel that way.

As I expected I didn't get up very early. I woke up at
930 and thought I would lie there until 10 but I fell
asleep again and didn't wake again until 1130.

After doing an air sample I read most of the afternoon
I am learning a great deal from Hunters of the Great North
and was especially please to come a pa across a passage
on dog driving which was my theory of dog driving in black
and white; it goes as follows. page 118. "The Eskimo idea
was that a dog should be treated with great consideration, and
his opinion was that a good dog would pull about as long as he
has any strength without being whipped. . . . that the only
approved Eskimo method of inducing dogs to work is either by
shouting to them and trying to cheer them up by the voice, or else
by having some person walk ahead of the team of whom the dogs
are so fond that they will pull hard to try to keep up. I
regret to say that during the twelve years following 1906 the
Mackenzie River Eskimos adopted the custom of whipping dogs."
. . . . that whipping tired dogs was one of the white man's
customs."
Lockhart quotes this long passage out of order. The clause "that whipping tired dogs was one of the white man's customs" occurs before the rest of the passage quoted here Stefansson 118. My short experience on the trail has leadled me to
agree whole heartedly with this. I do whip a lead
dog when he won't keep his line tight but only enough to
convince the dog that he is doing something wrong. These
dogs are so intelligent that they know when they aren't
working as they should. I never beat a dog and never
hit one hard enough to lame it or make it sore.

As a governor on my impatience I usually use my hand
26
knowing that I won't hit hard enought to hurt my hand.
One day, however, Sheila tried to bite me when I was
freeing her from the gang line and I really laced into
her. Biting is one thing that should never be tolerated in
dogs. Sometimes when I have boxed Spot's ears he has
reached up and taken my gloved hand but to show he
was only protesting my action he never closed down

I have noticed several times the pups which are running
loose, would try to steal a piece of meat from one of the tethered
dogs. The true viciousness of the large dogs immediately comes
out and luckily for the small dogs they scamper away but only
in the nick of time. I should hate to say what would happen
to a pup should a dog like Spot get a good grip on it when
no one was around.

I am trying to train Spot not to touch his meat until
I tell him to. He does very well and lets me take meat
away from him after he has started to eat. He is really
a good dog. I sent a message to Beatie telling her
to feed Pete well because I was bringing a 90 lb dog
home. Just wait until they see him.

This evening we had a reshow of Blondie which made
us laugh as much as if it were only the first time we had
seen it.

I have Perk in the basket tomorrow so I think I
shall go to bed now. It is almost two AM.
Cruzen has been made a commander.
The dog teams should be in sometime soon—several days.

Things have been happening around here so rapidly
that I haven't been able to find time even to sit down
for a few minutes and at the moment I shall be
able to make only a few notes.

Today at 8 PM we hear that the Bear was
only 190 miles from the Bay and with clear sailing
should be in tomorrow afternoon about 6 PM. Jack and
Doug have taken a trail tent down to the barrier and
are spending the nigth there. I doubt, however, that they
will be the first to see the Bear come in. She won't
really be able to come in because the ice hasn't gone
out yet. We not may have a job loading stuff but
at right now we hope only to be able to get out far
enough so that we can get our mail.

The weather was good enough today so that the
Beechcraft was able to make two flights out to the Conder.
The drift sought some radio gear and all the dauffle bags
sm minus some of their content were brought in. The
Conder is now at the mercy of the elements forever.

During the past three days I have been making
daily runs down to the old cache to pick up a seal and
bring it back to camp. Twelve seal have been killed so far
and about 6 have been brought back. Today while
I was down onn the bay ice having parked the team up
above on the barrier my companions, Tony Doc and Joe
Wells, and I were disturbed in our picture taking and
28
fun with the seals by the noise of a dog fight. We
hurried up and found the team had moved about
100 yards and that most of the dogs were all tangled
up. After straightening them up I found Shippy
tangled up in his harness and a sorry looking mess
he had a bad gash under his left forearm and was
in such poor shape although alive that if Joe had
had any shells left in the 45 I should have put him
out of his misery right then. I tied him on the sled and
had Tonyhold him while we made the trip back to camp.
After arrival at camp I went in to get a revolver and shells
and told Siple that I was going to shoot the dog. He
wanted me to get Dick's opinion on the dog's condition. When
Dick saw him he said he had seen dogs in worse condition
and that I sould let Shippy stay in the machine shop
for a while I really didn't want to do this because
Shippyhad been a good dog, had done his work well and
probably would be okay if he lived to reach the states.
I would rather shoot my dogs there than subject them to a
sea voyage none of them likes because most of them are
not pets and most likely will be done away with later on.
Well, I left him in the medicineshop until after dinner
when he began throwing up. I spoke to Dickagain and
he said since it was my dog I could do whatever I
wanted with him. I took him out to the wind moa
around the old cedarhaand gave him two shots
Troyaccompanied me to see his old friend die a death
29
probably more humane than any of the other dogs would get.
As we watched him after the shot had been fired his
tail wagged a few times and we thought he must
be enjoying a whole seal in dog heaven. Without
doubt Shippywill live in my mind long after the
others have become faded memories. He well deserves
it because he was one of my best dogs.

The tractor party came back Monday morning about
7AM. They made a min o tapdash in from 90. fantastically
for our party they brought in with them our dog sled with
all our extra gear on it.

The dog team party came in Tuesday morning. They
they had camped at Fort Wiener Monday night but left
at 3AM Tuesday morning. The survey party came in first
about 9AM. Ike Schlossback was the last man in. All
all of them looked as crumby as our party did when we
arrived.

Now that everyone is in and the trail season is over
this loosens our Party's moods. A lot of Fitz's gear, two
of Dick's dogs, 3 of Bursey's and one of Larry's and of
common the Condor.

I shall take Fitz in the bashel tomorrow for the start
in the trail parties. There are only 6 men I want to get
but there may be a repeat in the group. I am planning
on a week.
Day of days. The Bear has came in.

I didn't get to bed until about 6 that morning. Arnold wanted
me to do our andyin he thought would be continental air
he thought I might take a sample and do the analysis tomorrow
but since I have only one willching bottle and I needed that for
this morning. I had to finish the analysis almost immediately.
In the meantime I took a bath. Wonder of wonders! Actually
I think I was ashamed into it, by the way the boys who came
in from the trail meticulously removed the layers of dirt that had
accumulated while vacationing in the mountains.

After doing the analysis I went to bed for a few hours and
then ran a metabolism test on Fitz.

About four o'clok the Bear came in on the radio and said
that they would be in at 5:30. However since they did not
realize how close they were to the bay and they were already tied
up when I arrived on the ceene at quarter of five. After the
crew had sunk the dead men a group of us were welcomed around
by Captain Cruzen and then we went out to the admiral's
quarter's (unoccupied) and recieved our mail. I was one
of the most fortunate ones and had a large bundle including
some files and some candy. I also received the money I had
asked for. I hardly knew which letter to open first but
decided to open the smallest one and save the big one, like
Reasie's and Carl's and Jean's for the end because they would
cover most of the hintin which I care especially intrusted.
I read a few in the ship and then ami back to the base above

I read them all all over again. I had one from May
which had in it some pictures of Carl and her and
one of one of her sisters. I enjoyed also the pictures
Beatie sent of Pete, Peter, Papa, and the house. Both
Van I and Vivian sent letters with pictures in them of the
new baby. George also sent pictures in his letter. Other
letters came from Dave and Mary, Henery, Dot, Elenore
Jenene. Is I had one of of the most pleasant of times
I have had in a long while.

Some of the boys from the west came up to the base
and Tony had I thought had a great time showing them around
and telling them all his experiences.
With the coming of the Bear the Exploration really is on the
wane. The Star will be in after a couple of weeks and
West Base will become a thing of the past. The sooner
the better.

This place has become a mad house and an open
house. During the past few days everyone has been
irritation everyone else cause greatly little work has
been done. Movies have been shown to the sailors every
night and after the shows Buck takes them down to
the barrier on the West Base limited - the tractor with
the dog sled hitched on behind. I have given several
dog sled rides.

Today a little more order has prevailed. I ran a
32
metabolism test on Charlie Passel and am continuing
my air analysis. Arnold made a very valuable suggestion
and I shall follow it. I shall take air samples on the
way back and check the idea that the oxygen content
of the atmosphere varies with the latitude If this works out
I should have a curve showing on increase to East Base
or there about a decrease to the equator and there are
increases of air to Seattle. This would be something
worth while to the meteorologists and can be done with little
expendeture of time.

Park has two valuable finds both Ross seals a
male and female. These seals are very brave and have
not been reported for many years.

Recently Malcolm has threatened to take a walk
and Doc Frasier has made the recommendation that he
be watched constantly. One of the Expeditions projects on the
way home will be to get him back safely.

Tony is driving my team while I am busy and he
doesn't seem to be doing so well. He isn't as strict with
the dogs as I am and they, intelligent animals as they
are, take advantage of his good nature.

A hole has been made in the back of the food cache and
much of the stuff is being moved out.

Had Dick in the basket this morning; everything went
off alright.

For breakfast we had some fried eggs sunny side
up. The Bear exchanged several crates purchased in
New Zealand for some of our while frozen eggs. They
sure were good. I had these with some Virgina ham.

The wind had come up during the night and
about ten this morning the ice in the Bay began
breaking up and the Bear had to move out. If in
having to stay out all day. The ice which had expanded
from 1.5 to 2 miles past the new laviner cache all cracked
up and was being taken out by the SSE wind. It looks
as though it will crack out as far back as the cache,
which means a lot of Bay ice has to move out. It
also means that we may have an easier time loading
than was expected.

I read the reports of the expedition that have been
published in various newspapers and reprinted in the March
issue of the Polar Times. I have never seen such a
mess of rubbish collected together in one small volume in
my life. It was all "the Admiral this" and "Byrd that"
No matter where the airplanes flew the mountains they saw
had been previously "discovered" by Byrd. One clipping
also stated that the admiral made flights and took
pictures enough "to map accurately" about 35000 sq.
miles of new territory. We all know that they only
34
camera taken on those flights was a Leica and no
attempt was made to make overlaps or circles of pictures.
It is doubtful whether the admiral knew accurately where
he was. The reports said he discovered new mountains
300 miles from here and we know that there are no
new mountains within 300 miles of the base. infact the
plows had to tax their range to the limit to get into
new territory. Our trail party was 300 miles from the
base and we didn't see any mountains that had never
been seen before. The blarney that was written about
the dangers we faced while unloading was exaggerated
so much that we wondered if we were on the same
expedition. It was hoped by all hands that since this
was a government expedition all of the exaggeration and
untruths would be cut out of the reports. We feel that
the type of publicity so necessary to a private expedition
wasis absolutely unnecessary for this expedition. However,
since Byrd seems to be the only one who is getting credit
for all the work done down here even though he has
had actually little to do with the goings on, it must
be he and his stooge Hawthorne who have contrived to
keep the exaggerations and untruths on the same high
plane as maintained on previous expeditions. Hawthorne
who is coming down in the Star presumably to collect
film journals diaries etc is suspected of having his
own ax to grind--a book on the expedition for the
Admiral--and consequently will have little cooperation

He has already done some funny things with film
entrusted to him when he came down last year so
I doubt that he will be given the same opportunity
this time. So far as some of us are concerned his
plans will be defeated because we have received orders
from Dr. Wade the chief scientist to turn in to him anything
that can have a bearing on our own scientific reports
This we shall gladly do because we trust him where as
we don't trust Hawthorne. No matter now. All
the dish will come out in the wash.

No metabolism test this morning but we did have
eggs sunny side up again. For the first time in my
life I ate four eggs at one sitting and I believe I
could have eaten a couple more.

All of the food going back much of the radio gear
meterological equipment and aviation gear has already
been taken down to the barrier edge. It looks as though
it won't be difficult to get all of the stuff going back
down to the cache. Once down there it won't take long to
load the stuff on the ships. The Star, by the way,
has been in Dunedin several days and should be here
about the 28th of the month. In another three weeks
we shall be leaving and glad to do so.

Tony had been doing a good job with the dogs even
if he does get lost now and then and the team
36
runs away occasionally.

I made up some Benedict's for Due and he shows
a negative test.

Pete and Wiener made their hop this afternoon. Pete
wants to crack this altitude record he set up last fall. Murry
is cosmic ray observer and also will take charge of the bottles
I sent up for air samples. When they came down I got
some pictures of the landing. Wiener had carried out my
instructions and I removed the flasks. They went up only to
17000 ft because the rubber tubing caused the wings to
vibrate. After dinner I got Buck to light his oxygen torch
so that I could seal off the flasks. It was unsucessful
because the pressure inside the flasks was so great that
holes blew outwere made in in the tubing where it was heated. I have
one flask that will be good enough for air analysis here
but only as an indicator.

I had a "gram" from his men saying she was sorry
not to have sent mail on the Star but would have letters
for me in Valpo.

I didn't do much else but sit around and talk to
Klimdike about Alaska. I went to bed after my
midnight metereological observation.

Had Jack Bussey in the basket this morning. I think
this will be the last because I want to have start
packing my stuff for home. The Star which is
leaving Dunedin tomorrow will be here about the 27th
and I want to have everything ready. I shall try
to avoid any last minute rush as I had in Boston
Most of the day was spent doing gas analyses.

Tony presented me not only with a special Bear
cachet but also with cancelled stamped envelopeds
bearing the cancellation stpaamps of the various places
visited on her trip down here. They make a very valuable
collection. When I get home I shall make a cachet
of linoleum or wood and cachet these envelopes. Then
they will be collectors items. I also shall have
Wallace the yeoman and postmaster aboard the Bear
cancel some stamped envelopes so that I can have
many left over after I send my mail out.

Not much activity in camp today. Pete made
several hops just for fun and also to make a
Bay of Whales sun aerial survey with Shirley doing the
photographing. Jack R. and Fitz layed out some
markers.
I spent some time reading funny parts.

Outgoing mail.
Folks Beatie, Carl, Mrs. Mann, Van, George, Laurie & Henry,
Burker, Bob Harris, Bill Leckie, George Low, H. D. Lockhart,
Priscilla, Dave, Dorothy, Mrs. Heiborn, The Guernsey'sGuernseys.

Extremely sorry to hear of Mr Mahans passing. Had been looking
forward to telling him of my many adventures. Feel certain
that he is resting more peacefully now than he did during recent
years. Anxious to get home to see you all again.

Arrived back at base for christmas. Had a wonderful trip. Awaiting
arrival of ships for mail they hold. Anxious to get back to see
everyone. Return via Valporaiso Panama and Seattle. May have a
few days to spend with you while crossing country. Arrive Seattle
middle April. Happy new year to all.

Still out on trail when you spoke over air. Reception very poor.
Sorry. Thanks for sending pictures to mother. Leave here for
Seattle end of January. Please pass word along to Karlstrom.
Arrive middle April. Be seeing you on way home if possible.
Happy new year.
